Dr. Hassan Ugail, PhD, is a Senior Lecturer at the School of Informatics, University of Bradford in the United [[Image:hugail.jpg]]Kingdom. Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the EPSRC peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences.
'''Early Life'''
Hassan Ugail was born in S. Hithadhoo, Maldives. He received his opportunity to continue is studies in the UK as a result of a presidential scholarship. ''' Academic Life'''
Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from King's College London. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at University of Leeds in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at University of Leeds until September 2002. Dr Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005.
'''His Work''' Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the PDE (Partial Differential Equation) method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion.
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive CAD modelling and computer animation, design analysis and optimisation for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
'''Further Reading''' "Efficient Geometry Parameterisation for Modelling and Animation" ((http://parametric.inf.brad.ac.uk/index.php) "Biharmonic Polynomial Surfaces for Boundary-Based Smooth Shape Design" (http://biharmonic.inf.brad.ac.uk/index.php)
'''Source''' University of Bradford: School of Informatics [Staff Contacts] <http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=p&u=hugail>[[Image:Example.jpg]]

== Early Life ==
Hassan Ugail was born in Hithadhoo [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hithadhoo_%28Seenu_Atoll%29| Hithadhoo], Maldives [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maldive_Islands]. He received his opportunity to continue is studies in the UK as a result of a presidential scholarship.
== Academic Life ==
Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from King's College London. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at University of Leeds in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at University of Leeds until September 2002. Dr Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005.
== His Work ==
Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the PDE (Partial Differential Equation) method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion.
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive CAD modelling and computer animation, design analysis and optimisation for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.

Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the EPSRC peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences. == Early Life == Hassan Ugail was born in [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hithadhoo_%28Seenu_Atoll%29 |Hithadhoo],[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maldive_Islands | Maldives]. He received his opportunity to continue is studies in the UK as a result of a presidential scholarship. == Academic Life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from King's College London. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at University of Leeds in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at University of Leeds until September 2002. Dr Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. == His Work == Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the PDE (Partial Differential Equation) method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive CAD modelling and computer animation, design analysis and optimisation for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs. His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail] == Trivia == In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html | "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. <!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:hugail.jpg|thumb|Dr. Hassan Hugail as he appears on his staff profile at the University of Bradford. .|right]] --> '''Dr. Hassan Ugail, PhD''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist at the School of Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) [http://www.epsrc.ac.uk] peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early Life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu_Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive_Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education from Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu_Atoll)|Hithadhoo]] and 1987 moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to complete his secondary education at [[English Prepratory And Secondary School]] and at [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and was considered to be bright. He received his opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.
== Academic Life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Dr Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005.
== His Work == Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE Surfaces | PDE (Partial Differential Equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Dr Ugail also developed the method of [[Biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive Computer-aided design and computer animation, design analysis and optimisation for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.

Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education from Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987 he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to complete his secondary education at [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and was considered to be bright. In 1992 he received his opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship. Ugail currently lives in UK with wife Aminath Muna and kids (Neena Ugail and Noah Ugail).
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Dr Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005.
== His work == Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Dr Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
Dr Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]
== Trivia == In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html |"Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Dr. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
==Further reading== *[http://parametric.inf.brad.ac.uk/index.php ''Efficient Geometry Parameterisation for Modelling and Animation''] *[http://biharmonic.inf.brad.ac.uk/index.php ''Biharmonic Polynomial Surfaces for Boundary-Based Smooth Shape Design'']
Dr Ugail's recent research in the area of 3D modelling and animation has been reported in the media. Examples include, Yorkshire Post [http://www.ypn.co.uk/ViewArticle2.aspx?SectionID=55&ArticleID=1223030], Innovations Report [http://www.innovations-report.com/html/reports/communication_media/report-50344.html], Yorkshire Forward [http://www.digitalyorkshire.org.uk/news_1046.htm], IOFILM news [http://www.iofilm.co.uk/news/article.php?id=69].
== Source == * [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=p&u=hugail University of Bradford: School of Informatics (Staff Contacts)]

<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:hugail.jpg|thumb|Dr. Hassan Hugail as he appears on his staff profile at the University of Bradford. .|right]] --> '''Dr. Hassan Ugail, PhD''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist at the School of Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education from Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987 he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to complete his secondary education at [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and was considered to be bright. In 1992 he received his opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship. Ugail currently lives in UK with wife Aminath Muna and kids (Neena Ugail and Noah Ugail).
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Dr Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005.
== His work == Dr Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Dr Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
Dr Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]
== Trivia == In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html |"Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Dr. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
On 17th August 2007 Dr Ugail gave a short interview live on "[[BBC World]]" regarding the referendum that decided on the form of government the new constitution of Maldives should adopt where Maldivians voted between a parliamentary or presidential form of government. This historic referendum was held on 18th August 2007. In his interview Dr Ugail expressed his doubts that the election itself would be free and fair.
==Further reading== *[http://parametric.inf.brad.ac.uk/index.php ''Efficient Geometry Parameterisation for Modelling and Animation''] *[http://biharmonic.inf.brad.ac.uk/index.php ''Biharmonic Polynomial Surfaces for Boundary-Based Smooth Shape Design'']
Dr Ugail's recent research in the area of 3D modelling and animation has been reported in the media. Examples include, Yorkshire Post [http://www.ypn.co.uk/ViewArticle2.aspx?SectionID=55&ArticleID=1223030], Innovations Report [http://www.innovations-report.com/html/reports/communication_media/report-50344.html], Eye for Film [http://www.eyeforfilm.co.uk/news.php?id=69], The Engineer Online [http://secure.theengineer.co.uk/Articles/292497/Realistic+models.htm].

Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first [[Maldivian]] to recieve the title of professor in the feild of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education from Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987 he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to complete his secondary education at [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and was considered to be bright. In 1992 he received his opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Fact|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford.
== His work == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]
== Trivia == In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html |"Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
On 17 August 2007 Prof. Ugail gave a short interview live on "[[BBC World]]" regarding the referendum that decided on the form of government the new constitution of Maldives should adopt where Maldivians voted between a parliamentary or presidential form of government. This historic referendum was held on 18 August 2007. In his interview Prof. Ugail expressed his doubts that the election itself would be free and fair.

== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. Ugail was a top student and was considered to be bright. In 1992 he received his opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]
== Trivia == In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
On 17 August 2007 Prof. Ugail gave a short interview live on "[[BBC World]]" regarding the referendum that decided on the form of government the new constitution of Maldives should adopt where Maldivians voted between a parliamentary or presidential form of government. This historic referendum was held on 18 August 2007. In his interview Prof. Ugail expressed his doubts that the election itself would be free and fair.

<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:hugail.jpg|thumb|Dr. Hassan Ugail as he appears on his staff profile at the University of Bradford. .|right]] --> '''Professor Hassan Ugail, PhD''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist at the School of Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education from Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987 he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to complete his secondary education at [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and was considered to be bright. In 1992 he received his opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His work == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]

Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.

<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:hugail.jpg|thumb|Dr. Hassan Ugail as he appears on his staff profile at the University of Bradford. .|right]] --> '''Professor Hassan Ugail, PhD''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist at the School of Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education from Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987 he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to complete his secondary education at [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and was considered to be bright. In 1992 he received his opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His work == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try and observe slight changes in facial expression and blood flow. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological detectors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]

In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His work == Professor Ugail's principle research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.

This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological detectors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.

Prof. Ugail's principle research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford {{citation needed|date=August 2013}}. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His work == Professor Ugail's principle research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expression and blood flow. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological detectors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']

== Early life == Maahil Zameer was born in [[thinadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|thinadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. == His work == Professor Ugail's principle research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.

The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expression and blood flow. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological detectors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']

Prof. Ugail's principle research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer based physical analysis and design optimisation that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford .{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His work == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expression and blood flow. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological detectors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant protifolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/ViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.inf.brad.ac.uk/staff/index.php?type=pu&u=hugail]
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']

Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principle research interests are in the areas of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based physical analysis that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. Prof. Ugail is a leader in this field and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high level research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford .{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His work == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expression and blood flow. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological detectors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail]
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award thus far.
Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [http://www.haveeru.com.mv/dhivehi/professor_ugails_column '' Professor Ugail's Column ''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.haveeru.com.mv '' Haveeru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.

Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principle research interests are in the areas of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based physical analysis that fall into the broad area of research known as Simulation Based Design. Prof. Ugail is a leader in this field and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high level research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford .{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His work == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research is particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which enables to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expression and blood flow. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological detectors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]
His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail]
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award thus far.
Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [http://www.haveeru.com.mv/dhivehi/professor_ugails_column '' Professor Ugail's Column ''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.haveeru.com.mv '' Haveeru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.

Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principle research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} . Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford .{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research on Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [http://www.haveeru.com.mv/dhivehi/professor_ugails_column '' Professor Ugail's Column ''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.haveeru.com.mv '' Haveeru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.
