[[File:Professor Hassan Ugail.jpg|thumb|right|Professor Hassan Ugail]]
Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principle research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in [http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5 ''geometric design'']. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.

Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.

Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research in Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [http://www.haveeru.com.mv/dhivehi/professor_ugails_column '' Professor Ugail's Column ''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.haveeru.com.mv '' Haveeru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.

== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in [http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5 ''geometric design'']. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research in Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.

Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first and to date the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in [http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5 ''geometric design'']. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research in Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [http://www.haveeru.com.mv/dhivehi/professor_ugails_column '' Professor Ugail's Column ''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.haveeru.com.mv '' Haveeru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Professor Hassan Ugail.jpg|thumb|right|Professor Hassan Ugail]] --> Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first and to date the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in Ga.villingili, [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in [http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5 ''geometric design'']. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research in Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed the him as Ambassador to the UK.
Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [http://www.haveeru.com.mv/dhivehi/professor_ugails_column '' Professor Ugail's Column ''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.haveeru.com.mv '' Haveeru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Professor Hassan Ugail.jpg|thumb|right|Professor Hassan Ugail]] --> Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first and to date the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in [http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5 ''geometric design'']. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research in Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Professor Hassan Ugail.jpg|thumb|right|Professor Hassan Ugail]] --> Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first and to date the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in [http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5 ''geometric design'']. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research in Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Professor Hassan Ugail.jpg|thumb|right|Professor Hassan Ugail]] --> Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics; the [[University of Bradford]]. Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first and to date the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in [http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5 ''geometric design'']. He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the [http://www.visual-computing.brad.ac.uk/ ''Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford''].
== His research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Some of his achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object are all protected under British and US patent laws.
His [http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php ''research in Visual Computing techniques''] has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company [http://www.tangentix.com/ ''Tangentix Ltd''] looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games. Tangentix has recently launched [http://www.gamesessions.com ''GameSessions''] which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800 ''new lie detector''] system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile. This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors. Prof Ugail's system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, [http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php ''the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'']
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Professor Hassan Ugail.jpg|thumb|right|Professor Hassan Ugail]] --> {{Infobox scientist | name = Hassan Ugail | native_name = <!--Requires a native speaker to confirm--> | native_name_lang = div | birth_place = [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Addu City]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]] | birth_date = | fields = [[Visual Computing]] | thesis_title = Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment | thesis_url = https://leeds.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/fulldisplay?vid=44LEE_INST:VU1&docid=alma991006070719705181 | thesis_year = 2000 | alma_mater = {{Plainlist| * [[Kings College London]] (BSc 1995, PGCE 1996) * [[University of Leeds]] (PhD 2000)}} <ref>{{cite web|title=Hassan Ugail, Professor of Visual Computing, Faculty of Engineering & Informatics / Media Design and Technology - Staff Profiles| url=https://www.brad.ac.uk/staff/hugail|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> | workplaces = {{Plainlist| * [[University of Leeds]] <small>Research Fellow (20002002)</small> * [[University of Bradford]] <small>(2002present)</small>}} }} Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics at the [[University of Bradford]].<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile">{{cite web |url=https://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail|title=University of Bradford: School of Engineering and Informatics (Staff Contacts)|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first and to date the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|dead-url=yes|title=Ugail's vision of breeding Maldivian scientists|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20160303231903/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|archive-date=2016-03-03|website=[[Haveeru]]}}</ref>
Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford.<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile" />
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object{{citation needed|date=August 2019}}; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object<ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422756|title=Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object|status=patent}}</ref>; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object <ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422757|title=Time-dependent animation of a 3d object|status=patent}}</ref> are all protected under British and US patent laws.{{When|date=August 2019}}
His research in Visual Computing techniques has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company ''Tangentix Ltd'' looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|title=Data Compression Company Tangentix Raises $2.1 Million|website=Pulse2.0 News|date=2013-03-24|dead-url=yes|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20140322014337/http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|archive-date=2014-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php|title=Professor invents visual computing techniques|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305182620/http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php|archive-date=2012-03-05|dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|website=Tangentix|url=http://www.tangentix.com/about|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612014713/http://www.tangentix.com/about|archive-date=2015-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://minivannews.com/society/maldivian-scientist-recognised-for-achievements-in-digital-knowledge-transfer-6371|title=Maldivian scientist recognised for achievements in digital knowledge transfer|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322030324/http://minivannews.com/society/maldivian-scientist-recognised-for-achievements-in-digital-knowledge-transfer-6371|archive-date=2014-03-22|newspaper=Minivan News}}</ref> Tangentix has recently launched ''GameSessions'' which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tangentix.com/product/gamesessions|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001073645/http://www.tangentix.com:80/product/gamesessions|archive-date=2015-10-01|title=GameSessions|website=Tangentix}}</ref>
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|title=Award for Bradford Professor|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-07-07|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20100707063635/http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|newspaper=Asian Express Newspaper}}</ref>
In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a new lie detector system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lie-detecting camera tracks facial blood flow|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20106077-1/lie-detecting-camera-tracks-facial-blood-flow/|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800|title=New emotion detector can see when we're lying|access-date=2019-08-12|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/09/13/lie.detector.thermal.imaging/|website=[[CNN]]|title=Thermal imaging turns up heat on liars|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airport to test facial lie detector|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8de3ee04-dd45-11e0-b4f2-00144feabdc0.html|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref> This system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date. {{citation needed|date=August 2019}}
Prof. Ugail's research work is funded by a variety of sources. For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. His research finding has been widely published in related international journals and conference proceedings. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed him as Ambassador to the UK.
Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail ''Professor Ugail's Opinion''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.mihaaru.com '' Mihaaru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.
== Selected works ==

===Patents=== * {{cite patent|country=WO|number=2011110855|title=Multimedia content delivery system|status=patent}} * {{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422756|title=Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object|status=patent}} <!--* {{cite patent|country=US|number=2006170676|title=Representing a 3D object with a PDE surface patch|status=abandoned}}--> * {{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422757|title=Time-dependent animation of a 3d object|status=patent}}

He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics at the [[University of Bradford]].<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile">{{cite web |url=https://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail|title=University of Bradford: School of Engineering and Informatics (Staff Contacts)|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. He is also the first and to date the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|url-status=dead|title=Ugail's vision of breeding Maldivian scientists|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20160303231903/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|archive-date=2016-03-03|website=[[Haveeru]]}}</ref>
Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He is a member of the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council ([[EPSRC]]) peer review college and also a peer reviewer for several related journals and conferences in his field of research.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford.<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile" />
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.

In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford.<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile" />

He is currently working as a Professor of Visual Computing at the School of Engineering and Informatics at the [[University of Bradford]].<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile">{{cite web |url=https://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail|title=University of Bradford: School of Engineering and Informatics (Staff Contacts)|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> Professor Ugail is the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in Mathematics. Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. Prof. Ugail is a leader in the field of [[Visual Computing]] and has greatly contributed to the development of the field by successfully delivering a number of high-profile research and innovation projects, publications and international lectures. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford.<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile" />
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.

Prof. Ugail's principal research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]] particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging and computer based simulations. == Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu City)|Hithadhoo]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]]. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. Ugail was a top student and considered to be bright. {{citation needed|date=August 2013}} In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford.<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile" />
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].

He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. == Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996 both from [[King's College London]]. Prof. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a Lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford.<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile" />

Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and is among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at University of Bradford.<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile" />
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and design optimisation that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], [[Spain]].
This research has many practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and bio-medical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, human heart and artificial limbs.
== Achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object{{citation needed|date=August 2019}}; for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object<ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422756|title=Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object|status=patent}}</ref>; and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object <ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422757|title=Time-dependent animation of a 3d object|status=patent}}</ref> are all protected under British and US patent laws.{{When|date=August 2019}}
His research in Visual Computing techniques has led to the establishment of a University spin-out company ''Tangentix Ltd'' looking at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|title=Data Compression Company Tangentix Raises $2.1 Million|website=Pulse2.0 News|date=2013-03-24|url-status=dead|archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20140322014337/http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|archive-date=2014-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php|title=Professor invents visual computing techniques|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305182620/http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php|archive-date=2012-03-05|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|website=Tangentix|url=http://www.tangentix.com/about|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612014713/http://www.tangentix.com/about|archive-date=2015-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://minivannews.com/society/maldivian-scientist-recognised-for-achievements-in-digital-knowledge-transfer-6371|title=Maldivian scientist recognised for achievements in digital knowledge transfer|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322030324/http://minivannews.com/society/maldivian-scientist-recognised-for-achievements-in-digital-knowledge-transfer-6371|archive-date=2014-03-22|newspaper=Minivan News}}</ref> Tangentix has recently launched ''GameSessions'' which will enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tangentix.com/product/gamesessions|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001073645/http://www.tangentix.com:80/product/gamesessions|archive-date=2015-10-01|title=GameSessions|website=Tangentix}}</ref>

In September 2011, Prof Ugail unveiled a new lie detector system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profile.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lie-detecting camera tracks facial blood flow|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20106077-1/lie-detecting-camera-tracks-facial-blood-flow/|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800|title=New emotion detector can see when we're lying|access-date=2019-08-12|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/09/13/lie.detector.thermal.imaging/|website=[[CNN]]|title=Thermal imaging turns up heat on liars|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> This new system he developed is a complete step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airport to test facial lie detector|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8de3ee04-dd45-11e0-b4f2-00144feabdc0.html|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref> This system is purely non-invasive and can be used in a covert situation, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.

For example, his current research grant portfolio from [[EPSRC]] can be found here [http://gow.epsrc.ac.uk/NGBOViewPerson.aspx?PersonId=104887]. A list of selected references for his work can be found here [http://www.brad.ac.uk/ei/media-design-technology/staff-profiles/profile/?u=hugail].
In late 2005, the political Maldivian webzine proposed a so-called [http://www.dhivehiobserver.com/articles/qasimforpresident.html "Dream Team"] to constituent a future government that would bring forth "democracy and prosperity" in the Maldives, that is currently under political turmoil. Despite Prof. Ugail's training as a mathematician, the compiler of this list placed him as Ambassador to the UK.
Aside from his academic work as a university professor, Professor Ugail continues to inspire people especially Maldivians in the field of science by giving motivational talks, running local television programmes on science and delivering science related information in enthusiastic and engaging ways. For example, he runs a science column, called [https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail ''Professor Ugail's Opinion''] in local Maldivian language in [http://www.mihaaru.com '' Mihaaru ''] - the most prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.
