In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=How I became Professor Ugail|url=https://coralglass.media/articles/how-i-became-professor-ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Coralglass Media}}</ref>
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and was among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford at the time. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at the University of Bradford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=Professor Hassan Ugail|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[University of Bradford]]}}</ref>
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and machine learning that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design and Machine Learning. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], Spain. His work on computer-based human face analysis based on [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] has introduced methods which are being practically utilised in the area of biometrics as well for applications in healthcare.
His research has practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, the human heart and artificial limbs. Other than that, his research using [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] is seen to be applicable to biometric identification such as [[face recognition]], non-invasive [[human emotion analysis]], [[lie detection]] as well as medical image understanding for diagnostic purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/articles/ai-tool-transform-transplant-system-save-hundreds-extra-lives-year|title=AI tool to transform transplant system & save hundreds of extra lives per year|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[National Health Executive]]}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/288390/20230301/new-ai-system-selects-donor-organs-more-accurately-humans.htm|title=New AI System Selects Donor Organs More Accurately Than Humans|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[Tech Times]]}}</ref>

Ugail's research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]], particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations and machine learning.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In the 1960s, Hassan Ugail's father, Ahmed Ugail, worked as a clerk at the British Royal Air Force base in Gan Island in the Maldives. According to Ugail, his father's access to English language resources and books from the British based in Gan Island provided him with academic opportunities from an early age.
In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=How I became Professor Ugail|url=https://coralglass.media/articles/how-i-became-professor-ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Coralglass Media}}</ref>
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and was among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford at the time. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at the University of Bradford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=Professor Hassan Ugail|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[University of Bradford]]}}</ref>
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and machine learning that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design and Machine Learning. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], Spain. His work on computer-based human face analysis based on [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] has introduced methods which are being practically utilised in the area of biometrics as well for applications in healthcare.
His research has practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, the human heart and artificial limbs. Other than that, his research using [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] is seen to be applicable to biometric identification such as [[face recognition]], non-invasive [[human emotion analysis]], [[lie detection]] as well as medical image understanding for diagnostic purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/articles/ai-tool-transform-transplant-system-save-hundreds-extra-lives-year|title=AI tool to transform transplant system & save hundreds of extra lives per year|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[National Health Executive]]}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/288390/20230301/new-ai-system-selects-donor-organs-more-accurately-humans.htm|title=New AI System Selects Donor Organs More Accurately Than Humans|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[Tech Times]]}}</ref>

Ugail's research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]], particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations and machine learning.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives. He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In the 1960s, Hassan Ugail's father, Ahmed Ugail, worked as a clerk at the British Royal Air Force base in Gan Island in the Maldives. According to Ugail, his father's access to English language resources and books from the British based in Gan Island provided him with academic opportunities from an early age.
In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=How I became Professor Ugail|url=https://coralglass.media/articles/how-i-became-professor-ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Coralglass Media}}</ref>
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and was among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford at the time. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at the University of Bradford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=Professor Hassan Ugail|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[University of Bradford]]}}</ref>
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and machine learning that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design and Machine Learning. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], Spain. His work on computer-based human face analysis based on [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] has introduced methods which are being practically utilised in the area of biometrics as well for applications in healthcare.
His research has practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, the human heart and artificial limbs. Other than that, his research using [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] is seen to be applicable to biometric identification such as [[face recognition]], non-invasive [[human emotion analysis]], [[lie detection]] as well as medical image understanding for diagnostic purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/articles/ai-tool-transform-transplant-system-save-hundreds-extra-lives-year|title=AI tool to transform transplant system & save hundreds of extra lives per year|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[National Health Executive]]}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/288390/20230301/new-ai-system-selects-donor-organs-more-accurately-humans.htm|title=New AI System Selects Donor Organs More Accurately Than Humans|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[Tech Times]]}}</ref>
== Achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object and for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object;<ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422756|title=Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object|status=patent}}</ref> and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object <ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422757|title=Time-dependent animation of a 3d object|status=patent}}</ref> are all protected under British and US patent laws, between 2008 and 2015.
His research in Visual Computing techniques has led to the establishment of a university spin-out company ''Tangentix Ltd'' that looked at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|title=Data Compression Company Tangentix Raises $2.1 Ugail was the founder and CSO of Tangentix Ltd. It was a UK-based startup exploring the use of 3D graphics compression. The company raised both Series A and Series B funding in 2013 and 2015, respectively, and was acquired by Toadman Interactive in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix to play major role in games sector thanks to funding|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/business/tangentix-play-major-role-games-sector-thanks-funding-1865373|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=Yorishire Post|date=8 May 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix secures a further funding round for gaming tech|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/01/22/tangentix-secures-a-further-funding-round-for-gaming-tech/|access-date=2020-08-12|website=[[TechCrunch]]|date=22 January 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gaming Startups in Sheffield|url=https://tracxn.com/explore/Gaming-Startups-in-Sheffield|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=TraCxn}}</ref>
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|title=Award for Bradford Professor|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-07-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707063635/http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|newspaper=Asian Express Newspaper}}</ref>
In September 2011, Prof Ugail showcased a lie detection system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profiles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lie-detecting camera tracks facial blood flow|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20106077-1/lie-detecting-camera-tracks-facial-blood-flow/|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref><ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/09/13/lie.detector.thermal.imaging/|website=[[CNN]]|title=Thermal imaging turns up heat on liars|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> This system is seen as a step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airport to test 'facial' lie detector|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8de3ee04-dd45-11e0-b4f2-00144feabdc0.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/HPRgd |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref> This system is non-invasive with the potential to be used in covert situations, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Maldives National Award Winners|url=https://presidency.gov.mv/NationalAwards/Winners?id=7&year=2011|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Presidency Maldives}}</ref>
Ugail is also seen as an inspirational figure, especially among Maldivians, and is known for giving motivational talks, and he runs local television programmes on science and delivers science related information. For example, he ran a science column, called ''Professor Ugail's Opinion'' in the local Maldivian language in ''Mihaaru'' - a prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mihaaru - Professor Ugail|url=https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Mihaaru News}}</ref>
Additionally, Professor Ugail undertakes some philanthropic work by delivering STEM knowledge through the ''Ugail Foundation'', primarily through ''theCircle by Ugail Foundation'', which has imparted coding, critical thinking and leadership skills, especially to young people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ugail Foundation|url=https://UgailFoundation.org|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Ugail Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=theCircle by Ugail Foundation|url=https://theCircle.ac|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=theCircle by Ugail Foundation}}</ref>

In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=How I became Professor Ugail|url=https://coralglass.media/articles/how-i-became-professor-ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Coralglass Media}}</ref>
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and was among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford at the time. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at the University of Bradford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=Professor Hassan Ugail|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[University of Bradford]]}}</ref>
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and machine learning that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design and Machine Learning. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], Spain. His work on computer-based human face analysis based on [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] has introduced methods which are being practically utilised in the area of biometrics as well for applications in healthcare.
His research has practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, the human heart and artificial limbs. Other than that, his research using [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] is seen to be applicable to biometric identification such as [[face recognition]], non-invasive [[human emotion analysis]], [[lie detection]] as well as medical image understanding for diagnostic purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/articles/ai-tool-transform-transplant-system-save-hundreds-extra-lives-year|title=AI tool to transform transplant system & save hundreds of extra lives per year|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[National Health Executive]]}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/288390/20230301/new-ai-system-selects-donor-organs-more-accurately-humans.htm|title=New AI System Selects Donor Organs More Accurately Than Humans|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[Tech Times]]}}</ref>

In September 2011, Prof Ugail showcased a lie detection system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profiles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lie-detecting camera tracks facial blood flow|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20106077-1/lie-detecting-camera-tracks-facial-blood-flow/|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref><ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/09/13/lie.detector.thermal.imaging/|website=[[CNN]]|title=Thermal imaging turns up heat on liars|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> This system is seen as a step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airport to test 'facial' lie detector|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8de3ee04-dd45-11e0-b4f2-00144feabdc0.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/HPRgd |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref> This system is non-invasive with the potential to be used in covert situations, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Maldives National Award Winners|url=https://presidency.gov.mv/NationalAwards/Winners?id=7&year=2011|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Presidency Maldives}}</ref>
Ugail is also seen as an inspirational figure, especially among Maldivians, and is known for giving motivational talks, and he runs local television programmes on science and delivers science related information. For example, he ran a science column, called ''Professor Ugail's Opinion'' in the local Maldivian language in ''Mihaaru'' - a prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mihaaru - Professor Ugail|url=https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Mihaaru News}}</ref>
Additionally, Professor Ugail undertakes some philanthropic work by delivering STEM knowledge through the ''Ugail Foundation'', primarily through ''theCircle by Ugail Foundation'', which has imparted coding, critical thinking and leadership skills, especially to young people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ugail Foundation|url=https://UgailFoundation.org|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Ugail Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=theCircle by Ugail Foundation|url=https://theCircle.ac|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=theCircle by Ugail Foundation}}</ref>

{{Short description|Maldivian mathematician and computer scientist}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Hassan Ugail | native_name = | native_name_lang = Dhivehi | birth_place = [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo, Addu City]], [[Maldive Islands|Maldives]] | birth_date = 24 September | nationality = Maldivian | fields = [[Visual Computing]] | thesis_title = Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment | thesis_url = https://leeds.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/fulldisplay?vid=44LEE_INST:VU1&docid=alma991006070719705181 | thesis_year = 2000 | alma_mater = {{Plainlist| * [[King's College London]] (BSc 1995, PGCE 1996) * [[University of Leeds]] (PhD 2000)}}<ref>{{cite web|title=Hassan Ugail, Professor of Visual Computing, Faculty of Engineering & Informatics / Media Design and Technology - Staff Profiles| url=https://www.brad.ac.uk/staff/hugail|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> | workplaces = {{Plainlist| * [[University of Leeds]] Research Fellow (20002002) * [[University of Bradford]] (2002present)}} | image = | image_size = | caption = }} Professor '''Hassan Ugail''' is a mathematician and a computer scientist. He is currently working as a professor of visual computing at the Faculty of Engineering and Informatics at the [[University of Bradford]].<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile">{{cite web |url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=University of Bradford: School of Engineering and Informatics (Staff Contacts)|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> Ugail is known to be the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in mathematics. He is also the first and, to date, the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|url-status=dead|title=Ugail's vision of breeding Maldivian scientists|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231903/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|archive-date=2016-03-03|website=[[Haveeru]]}}</ref>
Ugail is known for his contributions on computer-based human face analysis including, face recognition,<ref name="halffacerecognition">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/05/190501114602.htm|title=Half a face enough for recognition technology|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> face ageing,<ref name="PrinceGeorgeFacePredicted">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uk-future-face/prince-georges-future-face-predicted-by-scientists-idUSKCN0SZ1O420151110|title=Prince George's future face predicted by scientists|newspaper=Reuters |date=10 November 2015 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="NewFaceAgeingTechnique">{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tech/new-face-ageing-technique-could-10622627|title=New face-ageing technique could boost search for missing people like Ben Needham and Maddy McCann|website=[[Daily Mirror]] |date=14 June 2017 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> emotion analysis<ref name="LyingEyes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertglatter/2019/07/30/don-henley-was-right-you-cant-hide-your-lyin-eyes/|title=Don Henley Was Right: You Can't Hide Your Lying Eyes|website=[[Forbes]] |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="FakeSmile">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/07/190729111239.htm|title=How can you reliably spot a fake smile? Ask a computer|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> and lie detection.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800|title=New emotion detector can see when we're lying|work=BBC News |date=13 September 2011 |access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> For example, in 2018, he has used his face recognition tools to help unmask the two suspected Russian spies at the heart of the Salisbury Novichok poisoning case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/09/27/new-evidence-links-russian-state-to-berlin-assassination/|title=New Evidence Links Russian State to Berlin Assassination|date=27 September 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/02/21/the-search-for-denis-sergeev-photographing-a-ghost/|title=The Search for Denis Sergeev: Photographing a Ghost|date=21 February 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2018-10-08/salisbury-poisoning-suspect-alexander-petrov-is-really-military-doctor-alexander-mishkin-investigative-website-claims/|title=Salisbury poisoning suspect Alexander Petrov is really military doctor Alexander Mishkin, investigative website claims|date=8 October 2018 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]}}</ref> Additionally, in 2020, Ugail collaborated with the BBC News investigators to uncover an alleged Nazi war criminal, who settled in the UK, who could have worked for the British intelligence during the Cold War.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/extra/7z6huifsyj/the-nazi-in-the-family-stanislaw-stan-chrzanowski/|title=The Nazi in the family|access-date=2021-11-12|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
Ugail's research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]], particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations and machine learning.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title= An in depth interview with professor Ugail|access-date=2023-06-19}}</ref> He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In the 1960s, Hassan Ugail's father, Ahmed Ugail, worked as a clerk at the British Royal Air Force base in Gan Island in the Maldives. According to Ugail, his father's access to English language resources and books from the British based in Gan Island provided him with academic opportunities from an early age.
In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=How I became Professor Ugail|url=https://coralglass.media/articles/how-i-became-professor-ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Coralglass Media}}</ref>
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and was among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford at the time. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at the University of Bradford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=Professor Hassan Ugail|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[University of Bradford]]}}</ref>
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and machine learning that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design and Machine Learning. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], Spain. His work on computer-based human face analysis based on [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] has introduced methods which are being practically utilised in the area of biometrics as well for applications in healthcare.
His research has practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, the human heart and artificial limbs. Other than that, his research using [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] is seen to be applicable to biometric identification such as [[face recognition]], non-invasive [[human emotion analysis]], [[lie detection]] as well as medical image understanding for diagnostic purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/articles/ai-tool-transform-transplant-system-save-hundreds-extra-lives-year|title=AI tool to transform transplant system & save hundreds of extra lives per year|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[National Health Executive]]}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/288390/20230301/new-ai-system-selects-donor-organs-more-accurately-humans.htm|title=New AI System Selects Donor Organs More Accurately Than Humans|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[Tech Times]]}}</ref>
== Achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object and for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object;<ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422756|title=Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object|status=patent}}</ref> and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object <ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422757|title=Time-dependent animation of a 3d object|status=patent}}</ref> are all protected under British and US patent laws, between 2008 and 2015.
His research in Visual Computing techniques has led to the establishment of a university spin-out company ''Tangentix Ltd'' that looked at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|title=Data Compression Company Tangentix Raises $2.1 Million|website=Pulse2.0 News|date=2013-03-24|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322014337/http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|archive-date=2014-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite techniques|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305182620/http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php|archive-date=2012-03-05|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|website=Tangentix|url=http://www.tangentix.com/about|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612014713/http://www.tangentix.com/about|archive-date=2015-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite News}}</ref> Tangentix subsequently launched ''GameSessions'' that enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tangentix.com/product/gamesessions|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001073645/http://www.tangentix.com/product/gamesessions|archive-date=2015-10-01|title=GameSessions|website=Tangentix|access-date=2019-08-15|url-status=live}}</ref> Ugail was the founder and CSO of Tangentix Ltd. It was a UK-based startup exploring the use of 3D graphics compression. The company raised both Series A and Series B funding in 2013 and 2015, respectively, and was acquired by Toadman Interactive in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix to play major role in games sector thanks to funding|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/business/tangentix-play-major-role-games-sector-thanks-funding-1865373|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=Yorishire Post|date=8 May 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix secures a further funding round for gaming tech|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/01/22/tangentix-secures-a-further-funding-round-for-gaming-tech/|access-date=2020-08-12|website=[[TechCrunch]]|date=22 January 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gaming Startups in Sheffield|url=https://tracxn.com/explore/Gaming-Startups-in-Sheffield|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=TraCxn}}</ref>
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|title=Award for Bradford Professor|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-07-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707063635/http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|newspaper=Asian Express Newspaper}}</ref>
In September 2011, Prof Ugail showcased a lie detection system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profiles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lie-detecting camera tracks facial blood flow|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20106077-1/lie-detecting-camera-tracks-facial-blood-flow/|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref><ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/09/13/lie.detector.thermal.imaging/|website=[[CNN]]|title=Thermal imaging turns up heat on liars|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> This system is seen as a step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airport to test 'facial' lie detector|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8de3ee04-dd45-11e0-b4f2-00144feabdc0.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/HPRgd |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref> This system is non-invasive with the potential to be used in covert situations, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Maldives National Award Winners|url=https://presidency.gov.mv/NationalAwards/Winners?id=7&year=2011|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Presidency Maldives}}</ref>
Ugail is also seen as an inspirational figure, especially among Maldivians, and is known for giving motivational talks, and he runs local television programmes on science and delivers science related information. For example, he ran a science column, called ''Professor Ugail's Opinion'' in the local Maldivian language in ''Mihaaru'' - a prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mihaaru - Professor Ugail|url=https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Mihaaru News}}</ref>
Additionally, Professor Ugail undertakes some philanthropic work by delivering STEM knowledge through the ''Ugail Foundation'', primarily through ''theCircle by Ugail Foundation'', which has imparted coding, critical thinking and leadership skills, especially to young people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ugail Foundation|url=https://UgailFoundation.org|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Ugail Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=theCircle by Ugail Foundation|url=https://theCircle.ac|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=theCircle by Ugail Foundation}}</ref>

Ugail's research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]], particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations and machine learning.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ugail.live/en/insights/view/an-in-depth-interview-with-professor-ugail|title= An in depth interview with professor Ugail|access-date=2023-06-19}}</ref> He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In the 1960s, Hassan Ugail's father, Ahmed Ugail, worked as a clerk at the British Royal Air Force base in Gan Island in the Maldives. According to Ugail, his father's access to English language resources and books from the British based in Gan Island provided him with academic opportunities from an early age.
In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=How I became Professor Ugail|url=https://coralglass.media/articles/how-i-became-professor-ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Coralglass Media}}</ref>
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and was among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford at the time. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at the University of Bradford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=Professor Hassan Ugail|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[University of Bradford]]}}</ref>
== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and machine learning that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design and Machine Learning. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], Spain. His work on computer-based human face analysis based on [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] has introduced methods which are being practically utilised in the area of biometrics as well for applications in healthcare.
His research has practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, the human heart and artificial limbs. Other than that, his research using [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] is seen to be applicable to biometric identification such as [[face recognition]], non-invasive [[human emotion analysis]], [[lie detection]] as well as medical image understanding for diagnostic purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/articles/ai-tool-transform-transplant-system-save-hundreds-extra-lives-year|title=AI tool to transform transplant system & save hundreds of extra lives per year|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[National Health Executive]]}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/288390/20230301/new-ai-system-selects-donor-organs-more-accurately-humans.htm|title=New AI System Selects Donor Organs More Accurately Than Humans|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[Tech Times]]}}</ref>
== Achievements == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object and for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object;<ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422756|title=Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object|status=patent}}</ref> and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object <ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422757|title=Time-dependent animation of a 3d object|status=patent}}</ref> are all protected under British and US patent laws, between 2008 and 2015.

Ugail was the founder and CSO of Tangentix Ltd. It was a UK-based startup exploring the use of 3D graphics compression. The company raised both Series A and Series B funding in 2013 and 2015, respectively, and was acquired by Toadman Interactive in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix to play major role in games sector thanks to funding|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/business/tangentix-play-major-role-games-sector-thanks-funding-1865373|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=Yorishire Post|date=8 May 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix secures a further funding round for gaming tech|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/01/22/tangentix-secures-a-further-funding-round-for-gaming-tech/|access-date=2020-08-12|website=[[TechCrunch]]|date=22 January 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gaming Startups in Sheffield|url=https://tracxn.com/explore/Gaming-Startups-in-Sheffield|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=TraCxn}}</ref>
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|title=Award for Bradford Professor|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-07-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707063635/http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|newspaper=Asian Express Newspaper}}</ref>
In September 2011, Prof Ugail showcased a lie detection system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profiles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lie-detecting camera tracks facial blood flow|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20106077-1/lie-detecting-camera-tracks-facial-blood-flow/|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref><ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/09/13/lie.detector.thermal.imaging/|website=[[CNN]]|title=Thermal imaging turns up heat on liars|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> This system is seen as a step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airport to test 'facial' lie detector|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8de3ee04-dd45-11e0-b4f2-00144feabdc0.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/HPRgd |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref> This system is non-invasive with the potential to be used in covert situations, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Maldives National Award Winners|url=https://presidency.gov.mv/NationalAwards/Winners?id=7&year=2011|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Presidency Maldives}}</ref>
Ugail is also seen as an inspirational figure, especially among Maldivians, and is known for giving motivational talks, and he runs local television programmes on science and delivers science related information. For example, he ran a science column, called ''Professor Ugail's Opinion'' in the local Maldivian language in ''Mihaaru'' - a prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mihaaru - Professor Ugail|url=https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Mihaaru News}}</ref>
Additionally, Professor Ugail undertakes some philanthropic work by delivering STEM knowledge through the ''Ugail Foundation'', primarily through ''theCircle by Ugail Foundation'', which has imparted coding, critical thinking and leadership skills, especially to young people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ugail Foundation|url=https://UgailFoundation.org|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Ugail Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=theCircle by Ugail Foundation|url=https://theCircle.ac|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=theCircle by Ugail Foundation}}</ref>

== Research == Professor Ugail's principal research interests are in the areas of geometric design, computer-based physical analysis, and machine learning that all fall into a broad area of research known as Simulation-Based Design and Machine Learning. The focus of his research has been particularly upon a novel method for geometric design known as the [[PDE surface|PDE (partial differential equation)]] method developed at the University of Leeds. The PDE method is based on a suitably chosen PDE that enables to model complex shapes in an easy and predictable fashion. Prof. Ugail also developed the method of [[biharmonic Bzier surface]] for boundary based smooth [[computer representation of surfaces|surface]] design with Professor Monterde from [[University of Valencia]], Spain. His work on computer-based human face analysis based on [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] has introduced methods which are being practically utilised in the area of biometrics as well for applications in healthcare.
His research has practical applications, which include building new application environments for complex interactive [[computer-aided design]] and [[computer animation]], design analysis and [[Optimization (mathematics)|optimisation]] for engineering and biomedical applications such as accurate computer modelling of shapes of biological membranes, the human heart and artificial limbs. Other than that, his research using [[artificial intelligence]] and [[machine learning]] is seen to be applicable to biometric identification such as [[face recognition]], non-invasive [[human emotion analysis]], [[lie detection]] as well as medical image understanding for diagnostic purposes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationalhealthexecutive.com/articles/ai-tool-transform-transplant-system-save-hundreds-extra-lives-year|title=AI tool to transform transplant system & save hundreds of extra lives per year|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[National Health Executive]]}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techtimes.com/articles/288390/20230301/new-ai-system-selects-donor-organs-more-accurately-humans.htm|title=New AI System Selects Donor Organs More Accurately Than Humans|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[Tech Times]]}}</ref>
== Work == His methods for the representation of a three-dimensional object and for the storage and transmission of data representing a three-dimensional object;<ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422756|title=Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object|status=patent}}</ref> and his method for the time-dependent animation of a three-dimensional object <ref>{{cite patent|country=GB|number=2422757|title=Time-dependent animation of a 3d object|status=patent}}</ref> are all protected under British and US patent laws, between 2008 and 2015.
His research in Visual Computing techniques has led to the establishment of a university spin-out company ''Tangentix Ltd'' that looked at defining and manipulating complex digital data applied to develop computer games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|title=Data Compression Company Tangentix Raises $2.1 Million|website=Pulse2.0 News|date=2013-03-24|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322014337/http://pulse2.com/2013/03/24/data-compression-company-tangentix-raises-2-1-million-82884/|archive-date=2014-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php|title=Professor invents visual computing techniques|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305182620/http://www.brad.ac.uk/mediacentre/press-releases/Title_22177_en.php|archive-date=2012-03-05|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|website=Tangentix|url=http://www.tangentix.com/about|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612014713/http://www.tangentix.com/about|archive-date=2015-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://minivannews.com/society/maldivian-scientist-recognised-for-achievements-in-digital-knowledge-transfer-6371|title=Maldivian scientist recognised for achievements in digital knowledge transfer|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140322030324/http://minivannews.com/society/maldivian-scientist-recognised-for-achievements-in-digital-knowledge-transfer-6371|archive-date=2014-03-22|newspaper=Minivan News}}</ref> Tangentix subsequently launched ''GameSessions'' that enable users to try or buy PC games online with ease.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tangentix.com/product/gamesessions|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001073645/http://www.tangentix.com/product/gamesessions|archive-date=2015-10-01|title=GameSessions|website=Tangentix|access-date=2019-08-15|url-status=live}}</ref> Ugail was the founder and CSO of Tangentix Ltd. It was a UK-based startup exploring the use of 3D graphics compression. The company raised both Series A and Series B funding in 2013 and 2015, respectively, and was acquired by Toadman Interactive in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix to play major role in games sector thanks to funding|url=https://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/business/tangentix-play-major-role-games-sector-thanks-funding-1865373|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=Yorishire Post|date=8 May 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tangentix secures a further funding round for gaming tech|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/01/22/tangentix-secures-a-further-funding-round-for-gaming-tech/|access-date=2020-08-12|website=[[TechCrunch]]|date=22 January 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Gaming Startups in Sheffield|url=https://tracxn.com/explore/Gaming-Startups-in-Sheffield|access-date=2020-08-12|newspaper=TraCxn}}</ref>
In 2010 Professor Ugail won the most prestigious award from University of Bradford, the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|title=Award for Bradford Professor|url-status=dead|archive-date=2010-07-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707063635/http://www.asianexpress.co.uk/yorkshire/nov_01_09/bradford_award.php|newspaper=Asian Express Newspaper}}</ref>
In September 2011, Prof Ugail showcased a lie detection system that uses two cameras and a computer to try to observe slight changes in facial expressions and facial temperature profiles.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lie-detecting camera tracks facial blood flow|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20106077-1/lie-detecting-camera-tracks-facial-blood-flow/|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref><ref name="BBC News"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/TECH/innovation/09/13/lie.detector.thermal.imaging/|website=[[CNN]]|title=Thermal imaging turns up heat on liars|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> This system is seen as a step change from the traditional polygraph lie detector, which requires the subject to be wired up to a range of physiological sensors.<ref>{{cite web|title=Airport to test 'facial' lie detector|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/8de3ee04-dd45-11e0-b4f2-00144feabdc0.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/HPRgd |archive-date=2022-12-11 |url-status=live|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|website=[[Financial Times]]}}</ref> This system is non-invasive with the potential to be used in covert situations, where the person being monitored potentially knows nothing about it.
In 2011 Professor Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation. He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Maldives National Award Winners|url=https://presidency.gov.mv/NationalAwards/Winners?id=7&year=2011|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Presidency Maldives}}</ref>
Ugail is also seen as an inspirational figure, especially among Maldivians, and is known for giving motivational talks, and he runs local television programmes on science and delivers science related information. For example, he ran a science column, called ''Professor Ugail's Opinion'' in the local Maldivian language in ''Mihaaru'' - a prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mihaaru - Professor Ugail|url=https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Mihaaru News}}</ref>
Additionally, Professor Ugail undertakes some philanthropic work by delivering STEM knowledge through the ''Ugail Foundation'', primarily through ''theCircle by Ugail Foundation'', which has imparted coding, critical thinking and leadership skills, especially to young people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ugail Foundation|url=https://UgailFoundation.org|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Ugail Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=theCircle by Ugail Foundation|url=https://theCircle.ac|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=theCircle by Ugail Foundation}}</ref>

He is currently working as a professor of visual computing at the Faculty of Engineering and Informatics at the [[University of Bradford]].<ref name="ubradfordstaffprofile">{{cite web |url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=University of Bradford: School of Engineering and Informatics (Staff Contacts)|access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> Ugail is known to be the first [[Maldivians|Maldivian]] to obtain a PhD in mathematics. He is also the first and, to date, the only [[Republic of the Maldives|Maldivian]] to receive a [[professorship]] in the field of Science.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|url-status=dead|title=Ugail's vision of breeding Maldivian scientists|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303231903/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/feature/53370|archive-date=2016-03-03|website=[[Haveeru]]}}</ref>
Ugail is known for his contributions on computer-based human face analysis including, face recognition,<ref name="halffacerecognition">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/05/190501114602.htm|title=Half a face enough for recognition technology|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> face ageing,<ref name="PrinceGeorgeFacePredicted">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uk-future-face/prince-georges-future-face-predicted-by-scientists-idUSKCN0SZ1O420151110|title=Prince George's future face predicted by scientists|newspaper=Reuters |date=10 November 2015 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="NewFaceAgeingTechnique">{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tech/new-face-ageing-technique-could-10622627|title=New face-ageing technique could boost search for missing people like Ben Needham and Maddy McCann|website=[[Daily Mirror]] |date=14 June 2017 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> emotion analysis<ref name="LyingEyes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertglatter/2019/07/30/don-henley-was-right-you-cant-hide-your-lyin-eyes/|title=Don Henley Was Right: You Can't Hide Your Lying Eyes|website=[[Forbes]] |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="FakeSmile">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/07/190729111239.htm|title=How can you reliably spot a fake smile? Ask a computer|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> and lie detection.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800|title=New emotion detector can see when we're lying|work=BBC News |date=13 September 2011 |access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> For example, in 2018, he has used his face recognition tools to help unmask the two suspected Russian spies at the heart of the Salisbury Novichok poisoning case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/09/27/new-evidence-links-russian-state-to-berlin-assassination/|title=New Evidence Links Russian State to Berlin Assassination|date=27 September 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/02/21/the-search-for-denis-sergeev-photographing-a-ghost/|title=The Search for Denis Sergeev: Photographing a Ghost|date=21 February 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2018-10-08/salisbury-poisoning-suspect-alexander-petrov-is-really-military-doctor-alexander-mishkin-investigative-website-claims/|title=Salisbury poisoning suspect Alexander Petrov is really military doctor Alexander Mishkin, investigative website claims|date=8 October 2018 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]}}</ref> Additionally, in 2020, Ugail collaborated with the BBC News investigators to uncover an alleged Nazi war criminal, who settled in the UK, who could have worked for the British intelligence during the Cold War.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/extra/7z6huifsyj/the-nazi-in-the-family-stanislaw-stan-chrzanowski/|title=The Nazi in the family|access-date=2021-11-12|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
Ugail's research interests are in the area of [[Visual Computing]], particularly in the area of 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations and machine learning.
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ugail.live/en/insights/view/an-in-depth-interview-with-professor-ugail|title= An in depth interview with professor Ugail|access-date=2023-06-19}}</ref> He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. In the 1960s, Hassan Ugail's father, Ahmed Ugail, worked as a clerk at the British Royal Air Force base in Gan Island in the Maldives. According to Ugail, his father's access to English language resources and books from the British based in Gan Island provided him with academic opportunities from an early age.
In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received the opportunity to continue his studies in the UK as a result of a [[British Council]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=How I became Professor Ugail|url=https://coralglass.media/articles/how-i-became-professor-ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Coralglass Media}}</ref>
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000 for his research in geometric design.<ref>{{cite thesis|last=Ugail|first=Hassan|date=2000|url=http://lib.leeds.ac.uk/record=b2052933~S5|title=Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment}}</ref> He then worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. Ugail joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009 at the age of 38 and was among the youngest professors at the University of Bradford at the time. He currently serves as the director of the Centre for Visual Computing at the University of Bradford.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail/|title=Professor Hassan Ugail|access-date=2023-05-13|publisher=[[University of Bradford]]}}</ref>

He is the first and the only Maldivian to have received this award to date.<ref>{{cite web|title=2011 Maldives National Award Winners|url=https://presidency.gov.mv/NationalAwards/Winners?id=7&year=2011|url-access=limited|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Presidency Maldives}}</ref>
Ugail is also seen as an inspirational figure, especially among Maldivians, and is known for giving motivational talks, and he runs local television programmes on science and delivers science related information. For example, he ran a science column, called ''Professor Ugail's Opinion'' in the local Maldivian language in ''Mihaaru'' - a prominent and widely distributed newspaper in the Maldives.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mihaaru - Professor Ugail|url=https://mihaaru.com/professor_ugail|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Mihaaru News}}</ref>
Additionally, Professor Ugail undertakes some philanthropic work by delivering STEM knowledge through the ''Ugail Foundation'', primarily through ''theCircle by Ugail Foundation'', which has imparted coding, critical thinking and leadership skills, especially to young people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ugail Foundation|url=https://UgailFoundation.org|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=Ugail Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=theCircle by Ugail Foundation|url=https://theCircle.ac|access-date=2019-08-12|newspaper=theCircle by Ugail Foundation}}</ref>
