'''Hassan Ugail''' (born September 24, 1970) is a Maldivian mathematician and computer scientist. He is a professor of visual computing at the Faculty of Engineering and Informatics at the University of Bradford.<ref name="BradfordProfile">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Profile"]</ref>
== Research Interests == Ugail's research interests are in the area of Visual Computing, including 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations, and machine learning.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> His work in these areas has contributed to the development of new methods and techniques in the field of visual computing, particularly in the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning for biometric identification and healthcare applications.<ref name="ResearchGate">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref>
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. His early education laid the foundation for his interest in mathematics and computer science, which would later become his field of expertise.
== Education == In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received a [[British Council]] scholarship to continue his studies in the UK.<ref name="SangamFestival">[https://sangamfestival.co.uk/online-programme/professor-hassan-ugail/ "Sangam Festival"]</ref> This opportunity allowed him to pursue his passion for mathematics and computer science at a higher level.
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> His doctoral research focused on the design, analysis, and optimisation in an interactive environment, contributing to the field of visual computing.
== Career == After completing his PhD, Ugail worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. He then joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009.<ref name="BradfordProfile2">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Staff Profile"]</ref> Throughout his career, he has been involved in various research projects and has contributed significantly to the field of visual computing.
== Research == Ugail's research has been focused on the application of artificial intelligence and machine learning in the field of visual computing. His work on computer-based human face analysis has been utilized in the area of biometrics and applications in healthcare.<ref name="ResearchGate3">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref> His research has led to the development of new methods and techniques in these areas.
His research in Visual Computing techniques has also led to the establishment of a university spin-out company ''Tangentix Ltd''.<ref name="Crunchbase">[https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/tangentix "Crunchbase Profile"]</ref> The company focuses on the application of visual computing techniques in various industries.
== Awards and Recognition == In 2010, Ugail received the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award' from the University of Bradford.<ref name="Acit2k">[https://www.acit2k.org/ACIT/index.php/keynote-speaker/407-prof-hassan-ugail "Acit2k Profile"]</ref> This award recognises his contributions to the field of visual computing and his efforts in knowledge transfer.
In 2011, Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation.<ref name="SangamFestival2">[https://sangamfestival.co.uk/online-programme/professor-hassan-ugail/ "Sangam Festival"]</ref> This award recognises his innovative work in the field of visual computing.
== Patents/Inventions by Prof. Ugail ==
1. Multimedia Content Delivery System, GB: 20130024545, issued 2013,
2. Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object, GB: 20060173659, issued 2006,
3. Representing a 3D object with a PDE surface patch, GB: 20060170676, issued 2005,
4. Time-dependent animation of a 3D object, GB: 20060170688, issued 2005.

'''Hassan Ugail''' (born September 24, 1970) is a Maldivian mathematician and computer scientist. He is a professor of visual computing at the Faculty of Engineering and Informatics at the University of Bradford.<ref name="BradfordProfile">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Profile"]</ref>
== Research Interests == Ugail's research interests are in the area of Visual Computing, including 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations, and machine learning.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> His work in these areas has contributed to the development of new methods and techniques in the field of visual computing, particularly in the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning for biometric identification and healthcare applications.<ref name="ResearchGate">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref>
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]]. His early education laid the foundation for his interest in mathematics and computer science, which would later become his field of expertise.
== Education == In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received a [[British Council]] scholarship to continue his studies in the UK.<ref name="SangamFestival">[https://sangamfestival.co.uk/online-programme/professor-hassan-ugail/ "Sangam Festival"]</ref> This opportunity allowed him to pursue his passion for mathematics and computer science at a higher level.
== Academic life == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> His doctoral research focused on the design, analysis, and optimisation in an interactive environment, contributing to the field of visual computing.
== Career == After completing his PhD, Ugail worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. He then joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009.<ref name="BradfordProfile2">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Staff Profile"]</ref> Throughout his career, he has been involved in various research projects and has contributed significantly to the field of visual computing.
== Research == Ugail's research has been focused on the application of artificial intelligence and machine learning in the field of visual computing. His work on computer-based human face analysis has been utilized in the area of biometrics and applications in healthcare.<ref name="ResearchGate3">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref> His research has led to the development of new methods and techniques in these areas.
His research in Visual Computing techniques has also led to the establishment of a university spin-out company ''Tangentix Ltd''.<ref name="Crunchbase">[https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/tangentix "Crunchbase Profile"]</ref> The company focuses on the application of visual computing techniques in various industries.
== Awards and Recognition == In 2010, Ugail received the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award' from the University of Bradford.<ref name="Acit2k">[https://www.acit2k.org/ACIT/index.php/keynote-speaker/407-prof-hassan-ugail "Acit2k Profile"]</ref> This award recognises his contributions to the field of visual computing and his efforts in knowledge transfer.
In 2011, Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation.<ref name="SangamFestival2">[https://sangamfestival.co.uk/online-programme/professor-hassan-ugail/ "Sangam Festival"]</ref> This award recognises his innovative work in the field of visual computing.
== Patents/Inventions by Prof. Ugail ==
1. Multimedia Content Delivery System, GB: 20130024545, issued 2013,
2. Storing or transmitting data representing a 3D object, GB: 20060173659, issued 2006,
3. Representing a 3D object with a PDE surface patch, GB: 20060170676, issued 2005,
4. Time-dependent animation of a 3D object, GB: 20060170688, issued 2005.

'''Hassan Ugail''' (born September 24, 1970) is a Maldivian mathematician and computer scientist. He is a professor of visual computing at the Faculty of Engineering and Informatics at the University of Bradford.<ref name="BradfordProfile">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Profile"]</ref>
== Research Interests == Ugail's research interests are in the area of Visual Computing, including 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations, and machine learning.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> His work in these areas has contributed to the development of new methods and techniques in the field of visual computing, particularly in the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning for biometric identification and healthcare applications.<ref name="ResearchGate">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref> Ugail is particularly known for his work on computer-based human face analysis including, face recognition,<ref name="halffacerecognition">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/05/190501114602.htm|title=Half a face enough for recognition technology|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> face ageing,<ref name="PrinceGeorgeFacePredicted">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uk-future-face/prince-georges-future-face-predicted-by-scientists-idUSKCN0SZ1O420151110|title=Prince George's future face predicted by scientists|newspaper=Reuters |date=10 November 2015 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="NewFaceAgeingTechnique">{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tech/new-face-ageing-technique-could-10622627|title=New face-ageing technique could boost search for missing people like Ben Needham and Maddy McCann|website=[[Daily |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertglatter/2019/07/30/don-henley-was-right-you-cant-hide-your-lyin-eyes/|title=Don Henley Was Right: You Can't Hide Your Lying Eyes|website=[[Forbes]] |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="FakeSmile">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/07/190729111239.htm|title=How can you reliably spot a fake smile? Ask a computer|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> and lie detection.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800|title=New emotion detector can see when we're lying|work=BBC News |date=13 September 2011 |access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref> For example, in 2018, he has used his face recognition tools to help unmask the two suspected Russian spies at the heart of the Salisbury Novichok poisoning case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/09/27/new-evidence-links-russian-state-to-berlin-assassination/|title=New Evidence Links Russian State to Berlin Assassination|date=27 September 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/02/21/the-search-for-denis-sergeev-photographing-a-ghost/|title=The Search for Denis Sergeev: Photographing a Ghost|date=21 February 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2018-10-08/salisbury-poisoning-suspect-alexander-petrov-is-really-military-doctor-alexander-mishkin-investigative-website-claims/|title=Salisbury poisoning suspect Alexander Petrov is really military doctor Alexander Mishkin, investigative website claims|date=8 October 2018 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]}}</ref> Additionally, in 2020, Ugail collaborated with the BBC News investigators to uncover an alleged Nazi war criminal, who settled in the UK, who could have worked for the British intelligence during the Cold War.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/extra/7z6huifsyj/the-nazi-in-the-family-stanislaw-stan-chrzanowski/|title=The Nazi in the family|access-date=2021-11-12|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]].
== Education == In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received a [[British Council]] scholarship to continue his studies in the UK.<ref name="SangamFestival">[https://sangamfestival.co.uk/online-programme/professor-hassan-ugail/ "Sangam Festival"]</ref>

He was awarded his PhD by the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 2000.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> His doctoral research focused on the design, analysis, and optimisation in an interactive environment, contributing to the field of visual computing.
== Career == After completing his PhD, Ugail worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. He then joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009.<ref name="BradfordProfile2">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Staff Profile"]</ref>
== Research == Ugail's research has been focused on the application of artificial intelligence and machine learning in the field of visual computing. His work on computer-based human face analysis has been utilized in the area of biometrics and applications in healthcare.<ref name="ResearchGate3">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref> His research has led to the development of new methods and techniques in these areas.

{{Infobox scientist | name = Hassan Ugail | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1970|9|24}} | birth_place = [[Hithadhoo (Addu)]], [[Maldives]] | nationality = Maldivian | alma_mater = [[King's College London]] (BSc 1995, PGCE 1996), [[University of Leeds]] (PhD 1999) | field = Visual Computing | work_institutions = [[University of Leeds]] Research Fellow (20002002), [[University of Bradford]] (2002present) | thesis_title = Design, analysis and optimisation in an interactive environment | thesis_year = 1999 }}
'''Hassan Ugail''' (born September 24, 1970) is a Maldivian mathematician and computer scientist. He is a professor of visual computing at the Faculty of Engineering and Informatics at the University of Bradford.<ref name="BradfordProfile">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Profile"]</ref>
== Early life == Hassan Ugail was born in [[Hithadhoo (Addu)|Hithadhoo]], Maldives.<ref name="ResearchGate2">[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan_Ugail "ResearchGate Profile"]</ref> He completed his primary education at Nooranee School in [[Hithadhoo (Seenu Atoll)|Hithadhoo]].
== Education == In 1987, he moved to [[Mal, Maldives|Mal]] to continue his education at the [[English Preparatory And Secondary School]] and at the [[Centre for Higher Secondary Education]]. In 1992, he received a [[British Council]] scholarship to continue his studies in the UK.<ref name="SangamFestival">[https://sangamfestival.co.uk/online-programme/professor-hassan-ugail/ "Sangam Festival"]</ref>
== Career and Research == Ugail received a B.Sc. degree with First Class Honours in Mathematics in 1995 and a PGCE in 1996, both from [[King's College London]]. He earned his PhD in [[Visual computing|Visual Computing]] at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 1999.<ref name="ResearchGate2" /> His doctoral research focused on the application of [[Partial differential equation|Partial Differential Equations]] in interactive surface design.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Ugail |first=Hassan |last2=Bloor |first2=Malcolm I. G. |last3=Wilson |first3=Michael J. |date=April 1999 |title=Techniques for interactive design using the PDE method |url=https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/318009.318078 |journal=ACM Transactions on Graphics |language=en |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=195212 |doi=10.1145/318009.318078 |issn=0730-0301}}</ref>
After completing his PhD, Ugail worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. He then joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009.<ref name="BradfordProfile2">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Staff Profile"]</ref> Ugail's research interests are in the area of Visual Computing, including 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations, and machine learning.<ref name="ResearchGate2"/> His work in these areas has contributed to the development of new methods and techniques in the field of visual computing, particularly in the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning for biometric identification and healthcare applications.<ref name="ResearchGate">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref> Ugail is particularly known for his work on computer-based human face analysis including, face recognition,<ref name="halffacerecognition">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/05/190501114602.htm|title=Half a face enough for recognition technology|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> face ageing,<ref name="PrinceGeorgeFacePredicted">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uk-future-face/prince-georges-future-face-predicted-by-scientists-idUSKCN0SZ1O420151110|title=Prince George's future face predicted by scientists|newspaper=Reuters |date=10 November 2015 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="NewFaceAgeingTechnique">{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tech/new-face-ageing-technique-could-10622627|title=New face-ageing technique could boost search for missing people like Ben Needham and Maddy McCann|website=[[Daily Mirror]] |date=14 June 2017 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> emotion analysis<ref name="LyingEyes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertglatter/2019/07/30/don-henley-was-right-you-cant-hide-your-lyin-eyes/|title=Don Henley Was Right: You Can't Hide Your Lying Eyes|website=[[Forbes]] |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="FakeSmile">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/07/190729111239.htm|title=How can you reliably spot a fake smile? Ask a computer|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> and lie detection.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800|title=New emotion detector can see when we're lying|work=BBC News |date=13 September 2011 |access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref>
=== Forensic science and criminal justice === In 2018, Ugail worked alongside [[Bellingcat]] journalists to verify the identities of two suspected Russian spies at the heart of the Salisbury Novichok poisoning case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/09/27/new-evidence-links-russian-state-to-berlin-assassination/|title=New Evidence Links Russian State to Berlin Assassination|date=27 September 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/02/21/the-search-for-denis-sergeev-photographing-a-ghost/|title=The Search for Denis Sergeev: Photographing a Ghost|date=21 February 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2018-10-08/salisbury-poisoning-suspect-alexander-petrov-is-really-military-doctor-alexander-mishkin-investigative-website-claims/|title=Salisbury poisoning suspect Alexander Petrov is really military doctor Alexander Mishkin, investigative website claims|date=8 October 2018 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]}}</ref> Additionally, in 2020, Ugail collaborated with the [[BBC News]] investigators to uncover an alleged Nazi war criminal, who settled in the UK, who could have worked for the British intelligence during the Cold War.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/extra/7z6huifsyj/the-nazi-in-the-family-stanislaw-stan-chrzanowski/|title=The Nazi in the family|access-date=2021-11-12|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
== Awards and Recognition == In 2010, Ugail received the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award' from the University of Bradford to recognize his contributions to the field of visual computing and efforts in knowledge transfer.<ref name="Acit2k">[https://www.acit2k.org/ACIT/index.php/keynote-speaker/407-prof-hassan-ugail "Acit2k Profile"]</ref>
In 2011, Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation for his work in the field of Visual Computing.<ref name="SangamFestival2">{{Cite web |date=27 November 2011 |title=President Nasheed presents National Award of Honour and National Award of Recognition |url=https://presidency.gov.mv/Press/Article/6333 |url-status=live |website=The President's Office, Republic of Maldives}}</ref>
== Bibliography == * {{cite book|last1=Ugail|first1=Hassan|title=Deep Learning in Visual Computing, Explanations and Examples|date=2022}} * {{cite book|last1=Ugail|first1=Hassan|title=Multidisciplinary Data Visualization|date=2020}} * {{cite book|last1=Ugail|first1=Hassan|title=Computational Techniques for Human Smile Analysis|date=2019}} * {{cite book|last1=Ugail|first1=Hassan|title=Partial Differential Equations for Geometric Design|date=2011}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail University of Bradford profile] * [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Hassan-Ugail ResearchGate profile]

He earned his PhD in [[Visual computing|Visual Computing]] at [[University of Leeds]] in the year 1999.<ref name="ResearchGate2" /> His doctoral research focused on the application of [[Partial differential equation|Partial Differential Equations]] in interactive surface design.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Ugail |first1=Hassan |last2=Bloor |first2=Malcolm I. G. |last3=Wilson |first3=Michael J. |date=April 1999 |title=Techniques for interactive design using the PDE method |url=https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/318009.318078 |journal=ACM Transactions on Graphics |language=en |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=195212 |doi=10.1145/318009.318078 |issn=0730-0301|doi-access=free }}</ref>
After completing his PhD, Ugail worked as a post-doctoral research fellow at the Department of Applied Mathematics at [[University of Leeds]] until September 2002. He then joined the School of Informatics, University of Bradford, as a lecturer in September 2002. He was appointed as a Senior Lecturer in April 2005. Ugail became a professor in 2009.<ref name="BradfordProfile2">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Staff Profile"]</ref> Ugail's research interests are in the area of Visual Computing, including 3D geometric design, 3D imaging, computer-based simulations, and machine learning.<ref name="ResearchGate2"/> His work in these areas has contributed to the development of new methods and techniques in the field of visual computing, particularly in the use of artificial intelligence and machine learning for biometric identification and healthcare applications.<ref name="ResearchGate">[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/232640340_A_Short_Review_of_Methods_for_Face_Detection_and_Multifractal_Analysis "ResearchGate Publication"]</ref> Ugail is particularly known for his work on computer-based human face analysis including, face recognition,<ref name="halffacerecognition">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/05/190501114602.htm|title=Half a face enough for recognition technology|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> face ageing,<ref name="PrinceGeorgeFacePredicted">{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uk-future-face/prince-georges-future-face-predicted-by-scientists-idUSKCN0SZ1O420151110|title=Prince George's future face predicted by scientists|newspaper=Reuters |date=10 November 2015 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="NewFaceAgeingTechnique">{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/tech/new-face-ageing-technique-could-10622627|title=New face-ageing technique could boost search for missing people like Ben Needham and Maddy McCann|website=[[Daily Mirror]] |date=14 June 2017 |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> emotion analysis<ref name="LyingEyes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/robertglatter/2019/07/30/don-henley-was-right-you-cant-hide-your-lyin-eyes/|title=Don Henley Was Right: You Can't Hide Your Lying Eyes|website=[[Forbes]] |access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref><ref name="FakeSmile">{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/07/190729111239.htm|title=How can you reliably spot a fake smile? Ask a computer|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> and lie detection.<ref name="BBC News">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-14900800|title=New emotion detector can see when we're lying|work=BBC News |date=13 September 2011 |access-date=2019-08-12}}</ref>
=== Forensic science and criminal justice === In 2018, Ugail worked alongside [[Bellingcat]] journalists to verify the identities of two suspected Russian spies at the heart of the Salisbury Novichok poisoning case.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/09/27/new-evidence-links-russian-state-to-berlin-assassination/|title=New Evidence Links Russian State to Berlin Assassination|date=27 September 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2019/02/21/the-search-for-denis-sergeev-photographing-a-ghost/|title=The Search for Denis Sergeev: Photographing a Ghost|date=21 February 2019 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[Bellingcat]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2018-10-08/salisbury-poisoning-suspect-alexander-petrov-is-really-military-doctor-alexander-mishkin-investigative-website-claims/|title=Salisbury poisoning suspect Alexander Petrov is really military doctor Alexander Mishkin, investigative website claims|date=8 October 2018 |access-date=2019-11-12|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]}}</ref> Additionally, in 2020, Ugail collaborated with the [[BBC News]] investigators to uncover an alleged Nazi war criminal, who settled in the UK, who could have worked for the British intelligence during the Cold War.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/extra/7z6huifsyj/the-nazi-in-the-family-stanislaw-stan-chrzanowski/|title=The Nazi in the family|access-date=2021-11-12|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
== Awards and recognition == In 2010, Ugail received the 'Vice-Chancellor's Excellence in Knowledge Transfer Award' from the University of Bradford to recognize his contributions to the field of visual computing and efforts in knowledge transfer.<ref name="Acit2k">[https://www.acit2k.org/ACIT/index.php/keynote-speaker/407-prof-hassan-ugail "Acit2k Profile"]</ref>
In 2011, Ugail received the Maldives National Award for Innovation for his work in the field of Visual Computing.<ref name="SangamFestival2">{{Cite web |date=27 November 2011 |title=President Nasheed presents National Award of Honour and National Award of Recognition |url=https://presidency.gov.mv/Press/Article/6333 |website=The President's Office, Republic of Maldives}}</ref>

He is a professor of visual computing at the Faculty of Engineering and Informatics at the University of Bradford.<ref name="BradfordProfile">[https://www.bradford.ac.uk/staff/hugail "University of Bradford Profile"]</ref>
